title: How to Clean Black Mold in a Shower

steps.title: Open the windows and doors in the area for ventilation.
steps.content: Open the windows and doors in the area for ventilation. When using bleach, it's always a good idea to create good ventilation. Try to open as many nearby windows as you can, particularly if there's one in the bathroom. If there's not a window in the bathroom, place a fan blowing air out of the bathroom toward an open window.

steps.title: Put on gloves and goggles.
steps.content: Put on gloves and goggles. Choose gloves that won't let the mold through, such as rubber cleaning gloves or latex gloves. Don't touch the mold with your hands. Similarly, goggles are a good idea, as you don't want to flip mold spores into your eyes accidentally. [1] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source You may also want to wear a dust mask that filters out mold. These precautions will also protect you from the bleach.

steps.title: Mix 1 cup (0.24 L) of bleach into 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water.
steps.content: Mix 1 cup (0.24 L) of bleach into 1 gallon (3.8 L) of water. Measure out the water first, and then pour the bleach into the water. Use a spoon or a paint stick to stir it together so it is well mixed. Try not to splash it as you're stirring. Make sure you never mix bleach with ammonia, as it creates toxic gases. If you prefer, you can start out with an antifungal cleaning solution that doesn't contain ammonia, then follow up with bleach after you get most of the mold off. [2] X Research source If you donâ€™t have bleach, 3% hydrogen peroxide can also kill mold. Reader Poll: We asked 357 wikiHow readers which chemical solution they prefer to use to clean mold, and only 10% of them said 3% hydrogen peroxide. [Take Poll] While peroxide can be effective at removing mold, bleach may work better.

steps.title: Dip a sponge or cloth into the bleach solution and scrub down the mold.
steps.content: Dip a sponge or cloth into the bleach solution and scrub down the mold. Squeeze out the excess and begin scrubbing the moldy areas. Knock off as much mold as you can and dip the cloth or sponge back into the bleach solution as needed. [3] X Research source You can also rinse out the cloth in running water before dipping it back in the solution so you're not returning as much mold to your cleaning solution.

steps.title: Use a scrubbing brush where the mold won't come off.
steps.content: Use a scrubbing brush where the mold won't come off. If you have areas where you're having trouble removing the mold, dip a toothbrush or other scrubbing brush into the cleaning solution. Run it over the moldy areas, using a small circular motion to get the mold off. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Make a new bleach solution to spray and scrub down what's left.
steps.content: Make a new bleach solution to spray and scrub down what's left. Once you've scrubbed away all you can, pour a new mixture of bleach and water into a spray bottle, keeping the same ratio as you did before. Spritz the stains left behind, and let it sit for 15 minutes or so. [5] X Research source Once you've left it alone, run over it with a clean scrubbing brush. Wash off the bleach solution with clean water and let it dry.

steps.title: Spritz plain white vinegar over the area to take care of what's left of the mold.
steps.content: Spritz plain white vinegar over the area to take care of what's left of the mold. Don't mix the vinegar with water. Just put it in a spray bottle and go over the area to get it damp. Let the vinegar dry on the area, and it will help kill off the mold that's left behind. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Fix any leaks you can see.
steps.content: Fix any leaks you can see. If a leak is causing the problem, it's time to take care of that! Replace leaky faucet heads, for instance, or if the leak is more than you can handle, call in a professional to find and fix the leak. [7] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source If you don't fix the leak, the mold will just return.

steps.title: Spray the area down with vinegar after every shower.
steps.content: Spray the area down with vinegar after every shower. To help prevent the mold from coming back, keep a spray bottle in your bathroom. Then, spray down the walls and tub after you get done with your shower. The vinegar will help kill the mold spores. [8] X Research source If the smell bothers you, add a few drops of essential oil, such as peppermint, citrus, or tea tree oil, to help cover up the scent.

steps.title: Air out the bathroom after you shower.
steps.content: Air out the bathroom after you shower. If you have an exhaust fan, use it. If you don't, make sure to keep the door to the bathroom open after you shower so the air can dry out. Too much humidity in a small space can lead to mold. [9] X Trustworthy Source United States Environmental Protection Agency Independent U.S. government agency responsible for promoting safe environmental practices Go to source If you don't have an exhaust fan, try placing a fan in the door to blow the air into the rest of your home.

steps.title: Clean the bathroom once a week.
steps.content: Clean the bathroom once a week. Use a disinfecting cleaner to go over your shower and scrub it down. Pick a day to do it each week to make it easier to remember, and set up a reminder if you forget. [10] X Research source Make sure to change out your sponge or cleaning brush regularly, as it can grow mold, too.

steps.title: Use your air conditioning in the summer to keep the humidity low.
steps.content: Use your air conditioning in the summer to keep the humidity low. Pulling humidity out of the air is one of your AC's main jobs, so you should run it in the summer when it's humid out. If you don't have an AC, try using a dehumidifier to reduce the humidity. [11] X Trustworthy Source Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Main public health institute for the US, run by the Dept. of Health and Human Services Go to source If possible, keep the humidity in your home under 60%. Today's smart thermostats often have a way to change the humidity, at least in the summer. In the winter, it shouldn't be much of an issue.
